 Again, I'm not questioning either the 'truth' or the 'validity' of Christianity. Such considerations lie outside my (or anyone's) expertise and really don't interest me. That said, I hasten to add that the evidence suggests that Christianity and Christian doctrine evolved over time, and that such evolution was often, umm..., bumpy. Indeed, today's Christianity is about as diverse and fractured as it was at the time of Arius or Luther, and continues to evolve. But I think that, in order to truely understand Christianity (or, for that matter, any other religion), one must trace its origin and gradual evolution. One cannot simply dismiss the Gnostics or Arians based upon political or institutional outcomes without knowing what it was that they had to say. And what they had to say was part of the mosaic of early Christianity. Judgements as to whether they were right or wrong, or to what extent they were 'heretics', is baseless and, IMO, without substance.
